plugins.name: Styles Manager
plugins.description:
Effortless Style Management in Figma


Take full control of your colors, text styles, effects, and grids with Styles Manager ‚Äì the ultimate tool for organizing, duplicating, and editing styles in Figma. No more manual copying or messy style structures ‚Äì streamline your workflow and keep everything structured in just a few clicks!


Bulk Duplicate Folders & Styles

  1. Preserve the original hierarchy when duplicating styles and folders.
  2. Keep all Variables links intact for a seamless workflow.


Batch Selection & Actions

  1. Select multiple styles within a folder and apply actions at once.
  2. Duplicate or delete entire groups of styles instantly.


Full Control Over Text Styles

  1. Easily rename, duplicate, and delete text styles.
  2. Maintain the folder structure while working with multiple styles.


Instant Effect Type Recognition

  1. Identify Drop Shadows, Blurs, and Inner Shadows at a glance.
  2. Edit and organize effect styles as easily as colors and fonts.


Manage Grid Styles Efficiently

  1. Quickly duplicate, remove, or organize grid styles while preserving settings.
  2. Select multiple grid styles at once for bulk actions.


Why Use Styles Manager?


  1. Saves time by automating repetitive tasks.
  2. Keeps everything structured ‚Äì no more lost or unorganized styles.
  3. Ensures consistency across projects with preserved Variables and hierarchy.


Upgrade your workflow and take full control of your Figma styles today!

plugins.name: Pulpo
plugins.description:
Introducing the Pulpo Plugin for Figma, a powerful tool that seamlessly integrates your Figma files with Pulpo, providing you with a centralized platform to manage all your Figma comments.


With the Pulpo Plugin, you can effortlessly sync multiple Figma files, consolidating all the comments from each file into a single, unified space.


Gone are the days of juggling between different Figma projects to keep track of discussions and feedback. This plugin offers a streamlined workflow, allowing you to visualize and organize all your Figma comments in one convenient location. By bringing together comments from multiple files, you gain a comprehensive overview of the feedback received across your design projects.

Through its intuitive interface, the Pulpo Plugin empowers you to efficiently navigate through your comments, providing seamless access to the context and details of each conversation. You can easily respond to comments, resolve issues, or collaborate with your team members directly from within Pulpo.


With Pulpo's advanced features, you can also assign comments to specific team members, set due dates, and track the progress of discussions, ensuring that all feedback is addressed and actioned upon in a timely manner.


The Pulpo Plugin not only enhances your team's collaboration but also improves your overall design workflow. By centralizing your Figma comments, you can eliminate the need for constant switching between projects, saving you valuable time and effort.


Experience a new level of efficiency and organization with the Pulpo Plugin for Figma. Streamline your comment management process and unlock the full potential of your design collaboration.


For more info visit https://usepulpo.com/
plugins.tagline: All your Figma files comments in one place

plugins.name: Random values generator
plugins.description:
This plugin is created to help you save time and speed up productivity by allowing you generate random values with just a click.

You can quickly create numeric, alphanumeric, or pattern-based random values.

Whether you‚Äôre prototyping, testing input fields, or designing layouts, this plugin ensures precision and speed by generating values tailored to your needs.


How to use

  1. Run the Random Values generator plugin
  2. Select one or multiple text layers
  3. Select the type of values you want, enter your preferred number of character and click on ‚ÄòGenerate values‚Äù
  4. The pattern-based values allow you to define the format in which random values are generated. For example, by using "X" for random alphabets and "#" for random numbers, you can control the structure of the output. Separators such as - (dash), . (dot), and _ (underscore) can also be included to customize the format further.

Example Patterns:

X#XX## could generate D3FR53.

##XX#X-XX## could generate 06CO2M-FC92.

This feature allows you to create structured, randomized values for placeholders, tokens, or testing data with ease.


Use cases:

  1. Populating Placeholder Data : Use the plugin to generate realistic placeholder values for prototypes, such as: Unique identifiers (e.g., serial numbers, order numbers, or product codes).
  2. Form fields like usernames, passwords, or verification codes
  3. Generate unique codes and simulate real world data: Generate pattern-based values to mimic specific real-world data, such as: License plates, invoice numbers, customer IDs, coupons, gift card, events tickets
  4. Testing UI scalability: Check how your designs handle varying lengths and types of values, ensuring components like input fields, labels, and tables remain responsive and visually consistent.


Need any help or have questions? Please reach out


Show me some support
plugins.tagline: Generate random values for your project

plugins.name: Infa
plugins.description:
What is Infa

Manage your design system inventory directly within your product's webpage. Learn more at https://infa.ai/


What does the Figma Plugin for Figma unlock?

Pull all the screenshots and code snippets for your component views from Infa into FigJam. This enhances your design system review sessions by enabling visual and code comparisons of components. Navigate back to the component in your real product through our Chrome extension, ensuring that your design critiques are grounded in actual product usage.


How to Get Started:

  1. Install the Chrome Extension: Create components and select them within the Chrome Extension:https://infa.ai/chrome-extension
  2. Upgrade to Pro: Upgrade your account to Pro and upload your board to the cloud to connect your Figma plugin.
  3. Take Screenshots and Capture Code: Open component views in the Chrome Extension and click on "Take Screenshot" or "Capture Code" to make them available in your plugin.
  4. Authenticate: Open the Figma plugin and enter your API key from your Info account to authenticate. https://infa.ai/profile#api
  5. Import Components: Select the components to import screenshots and code into FigJam.


Contact Us:

For any questions or recommendations, please reach out to us at contact@infa.ai
plugins.tagline: New way of Conducting Design System Inventory and Visualizing Design System in use with Infa

plugins.name: To the top
plugins.description:
This Figma plugin allows me to move any selected objects to the topmost level of Figma page hierarchy, preserving their absolute positions on the canvas. No more manual dragging, dropping, or adjusting coordinates. Ideal for managing complex nested designs and maintaining a tidy layer structure. Less scroll layers, more control where and how you paste stuff.


It enables two use cases:

  1. Move all selected to the top -> cut -> paste in place in any selected frame or group without moving anything.
  2. Free guides and arrows from being cropped by their parent frames, which is helpful when preparing references and when some modals with clipping=on involved.


Differences from similar plugins - this one support multiple objects, and, doesn't move anything anywhere regardless of whatever coordinates starting pointüòä
plugins.tagline: Move selected elements to the top level of page hierarchy

plugins.name: IconAutomation
plugins.description:
### **Comprehensive Guide to the IconAutomation Figma Plugin**


#### **Introduction**


**IconAutomation** is a powerful tool designed to streamline and automate the process of publishing icons within Figma. By integrating with GitLab CI, this plugin ensures your icon sets are always up-to-date and consistent across all platforms. Whether you're a designer working on a small project or part of a large team managing complex design systems, IconAutomation saves time and effort while eliminating manual workflows.


This plugin is primarily tailored for enterprise scenarios. Our company aims to build an internal icon library using Figma and GitLab as a replacement for Iconfont, which suffers from the following limitations:


- **Management Complexity**: Managing Iconfont requires multiple accounts and frequent importing/exporting between design files, Iconfont platforms, and code repositories.

- **Icon Accumulation**: Over time, unused icons accumulate and are loaded all at once in projects, preventing on-demand loading.

- **Font-Based Limitations**: Font-based icons may render blurry or pixelated on high-resolution screens.

- **Icon Conflicts**: Conflicts can arise when using multiple Iconfont libraries, leading to incorrect icon displays.


IconAutomation addresses these issues by leveraging SVGs to build a scalable internal icon library. Once configured, updating both the icon library and code repository can be done with a single click. Unlike font-based solutions, SVGs enable granular control over icon usage‚Äîonly the icons actually used in a project are bundled, preventing unnecessary bloat.


#### **Core Features**


- **One-Click Publishing**: Publish icons directly from Figma with a single action.

- **GitLab Integration**: Seamlessly connect with GitLab CI/CD pipelines for automated workflows.

- **Version Control**: Automatically manage semantic versioning in `package.json`.

- **Diff Generation**: Compare current and historical icons to generate detailed change reports.

- **Branch Automation**: Create feature branches, submit merge requests (MRs), and clean up temporary branches automatically.

- **SVG Optimization**: Optimize icon assets for performance using industry-standard tools.


#### **Prerequisites**


- **GitLab Instance**: A deployed GitLab instance (cloud-based or self-hosted).

- **Template Repository**: Deploy the `react-icons` template repository to your GitLab instance.

- **Figma Client**: Install the IconAutomation plugin via Figma's Community portal.

- **Plugin Configuration**: Configure essential settings as outlined below.


#### **Configuration Guide**


##### **GitLab Settings**


- **Domain**: The URL of your GitLab instance (e.g., `https://gitlab.com`).

- **Project ID**: Found under your repository‚Äôs **Settings > General**.

- **Access Token**: Generate a token with `api`, `read_repository`, and `write_repository` scopes from GitLab‚Äôs **Profile > Access Tokens**.


##### **Figma Plugin Setup**


1. Install the plugin and grant necessary permissions.

2. Navigate to the plugin settings and input your GitLab domain, project ID, and access token.

3. Validate the connection to ensure seamless integration.


#### **Design Specifications**


##### **Page Naming Conventions**


- Pages intended for publishing **must** include the keyword "icon" (e.g., `product-icons`, `system-icons`).

- Only frames under these pages will be processed by the plugin.


##### **Frame Requirements**


- Frames must be named with one of the following suffixes:

- **Outlined**: For icons with stroke-based designs (e.g., `Navigation-Outlined`).

- **Filled**: For solid-filled icons (e.g., `Actions-Filled`).

- **Colored**: For multi-color icons, further categorized as:

- **Light**: Optimized for light backgrounds.

- **Dark**: Optimized for dark backgrounds.


##### **Icon Layer Rules**


- All icons **must** be Figma components (not frames or groups).

- Verify component status by selecting a layer‚Äîthe top panel should display "Component."


##### **Naming Standards**


- Use **Upper Camel Case** (e.g., `AlertCircle`, `SettingsGear`).

- Append style suffixes (e.g., `AlertCircleOutlined`, `SettingsGearFilled`).

- Avoid special characters (`-`, `_`, spaces) and numeric suffixes unless intrinsic to the icon‚Äôs name (e.g., `Star1` is allowed; `Star 1` is invalid).

- Ensure uniqueness within each category to prevent conflicts.


#### **Automated Workflow**


1. **Repository Setup**: Configure GitLab details in the plugin settings.

2. **Local Validation**:

- The plugin checks for naming compliance, duplicates, and structural errors.

- Invalid icons are flagged with actionable feedback.

3. **Branch Management**:

- A temporary branch (e.g., `figma-update-20231001`) is created from `master`.

- Semantic versioning updates `package.json` (e.g., `1.2.0` ‚Üí `1.3.0` for minor changes).

4. **Diff Analysis**:

- Compares current icons against the latest `master` commit.

- Generates a report detailing additions, modifications, and deletions.

5. **Asset Export**:

- Exports SVGs via Figma‚Äôs API and organizes them into folders (e.g., `/outlined`, `/filled`).

- Applies SVGO optimizations to reduce file size.

6. **Merge Request (MR)**:

- Submits an MR with a standardized title (e.g., `[Figma]: add icons`).

- Auto-merges after passing CI checks (linting, build tests).


#### **Best Practices**


- **Consistent Naming**: Adhere strictly to naming conventions to avoid validation failures.

- **Modular Design**: Build icons as reusable components with standardized dimensions (e.g., 24x24px).

- **Version Tracking**: Maintain a `CHANGELOG.md` to document icon updates and deprecations.

- **Performance Checks**: Audit SVG complexity to ensure optimal rendering (e.g., simplify paths for small icons).


#### **Example Scenarios**


##### **Scenario 1: Updating an Icon Set**


1. Add new icons to the `Actions-Filled` frame in Figma.

2. Run the plugin to validate and generate diffs.

3. Submit an MR to deploy changes to production.


##### **Scenario 2: Migrating Legacy Iconfont Icons**


1. Import existing Iconfont SVGs into a `Legacy-Outlined` frame.

2. Use the plugin to publish them as SVGs and update project imports.


#### **Troubleshooting**


| Issue | Solution |

| ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |

| **Naming Errors** | Check for invalid characters or duplicates using the plugin‚Äôs validation tool. |

| **Merge Conflicts** | Resolve conflicts manually in GitLab before re-running the plugin. |

| **API Timeouts** | Increase timeout thresholds in GitLab CI settings or split large icon sets. |

| **SVG Rendering Issues** | Convert strokes to outlines and simplify complex paths in Figma. |


#### **Future Roadmap**


- [ ] **GitHub Integration**: Support publishing to GitHub repositories.

- [ ] **Change Preview**: Display a summary of icon changes before publishing.

- [ ] **Enhanced Error Handling**: Provide contextual error messages with resolution steps.

- [ ] **Progress Tracking**: Add a visual progress bar for long-running tasks.


#### **Additional Resources**


- **Figma Documentation**: [Figma Help Center](https://help.figma.com)

- **GitLab CI/CD Guide**: [GitLab CI/CD Documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/)

- **Community Support**: Join discussions on Figma‚Äôs [Community Forum](https://forum.figma.com).
plugins.tagline: This is a plugin that combines Figma + GitLab to achieve automated publication of an icon library.

- Frames must be named with one of the following suffixes:

- **Outlined**: For icons with stroke-based designs (e.g., `Navigation-Outlined`).

- **Filled**: For solid-filled icons (e.g., `Actions-Filled`).

- **Colored**: For multi-color icons, further categorized as:

- **Light**: Optimized for light backgrounds.

- **Dark**: Optimized for dark backgrounds.


##### **Icon Layer Rules**


- All icons **must** be Figma components (not frames or groups).

- Verify component status by selecting a layer‚Äîthe top panel should display "Component."


##### **Naming Standards**


- Use **Upper Camel Case** (e.g., `AlertCircle`, `SettingsGear`).

- Append style suffixes (e.g., `AlertCircleOutlined`, `SettingsGearFilled`).

- Avoid special characters (`-`, `_`, spaces) and numeric suffixes unless intrinsic to the icon‚Äôs name (e.g., `Star1` is allowed; `Star 1` is invalid).

- Ensure uniqueness within each category to prevent conflicts.


#### **Automated Workflow**


1. **Repository Setup**: Configure GitLab details in the plugin settings.

2. **Local Validation**:

- The plugin checks for naming compliance, duplicates, and structural errors.

- Invalid icons are flagged with actionable feedback.

3. **Branch Management**:

- A temporary branch (e.g., `figma-update-20231001`) is created from `master`.

- Semantic versioning updates `package.json` (e.g., `1.2.0` ‚Üí `1.3.0` for minor changes).

4. **Diff Analysis**:

- Compares current icons against the latest `master` commit.

- Generates a report detailing additions, modifications, and deletions.

5. **Asset Export**:

- Exports SVGs via Figma‚Äôs API and organizes them into folders (e.g., `/outlined`, `/filled`).

- Applies SVGO optimizations to reduce file size.

6. **Merge Request (MR)**:

- Submits an MR with a standardized title (e.g., `[Figma]: add icons`).

- Auto-merges after passing CI checks (linting, build tests).


#### **Best Practices**


- **Consistent Naming**: Adhere strictly to naming conventions to avoid validation failures.

- **Modular Design**: Build icons as reusable components with standardized dimensions (e.g., 24x24px).

- **Version Tracking**: Maintain a `CHANGELOG.md` to document icon updates and deprecations.

- **Performance Checks**: Audit SVG complexity to ensure optimal rendering (e.g., simplify paths for small icons).


#### **Example Scenarios**


##### **Scenario 1: Updating an Icon Set**


1. Add new icons to the `Actions-Filled` frame in Figma.

2. Run the plugin to validate and generate diffs.

3. Submit an MR to deploy changes to production.


##### **Scenario 2: Migrating Legacy Iconfont Icons**


1. Import existing Iconfont SVGs into a `Legacy-Outlined` frame.

2. Use the plugin to publish them as SVGs and update project imports.


#### **Troubleshooting**


| Issue | Solution |

| ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |

| **Naming Errors** | Check for invalid characters or duplicates using the plugin‚Äôs validation tool. |

| **Merge Conflicts** | Resolve conflicts manually in GitLab before re-running the plugin. |

| **API Timeouts** | Increase timeout thresholds in GitLab CI settings or split large icon sets. |

| **SVG Rendering Issues** | Convert strokes to outlines and simplify complex paths in Figma. |


#### **Future Roadmap**


- [ ] **GitHub Integration**: Support publishing to GitHub repositories.

- [ ] **Change Preview**: Display a summary of icon changes before publishing.

- [ ] **Enhanced Error Handling**: Provide contextual error messages with resolution steps.

- [ ] **Progress Tracking**: Add a visual progress bar for long-running tasks.


#### **Additional Resources**


- **Figma Documentation**: [Figma Help Center](https://help.figma.com)

- **GitLab CI/CD Guide**: [GitLab CI/CD Documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/)

- **Community Support**: Join discussions on Figma‚Äôs [Community Forum](https://forum.figma.com).

plugins.name: popcons
plugins.description:
Popcons is a powerful Figma plugin that takes icon customization to the next level.

Unlike conventional icon libraries, Popcons allows you to instantly modify and compare different styles, just like fonts.


Once an icon is imported, you can edit, modify, and adjust it with a single button, eliminating the need for manual replacements.

With support for 6 thickness levels, 4 styles (Line, Solid, Line Color, Full Color), and 3 roundness options, Popcons provides unparalleled flexibility. Additionally, icons can be further enhanced with decorative elements to suit your design needs.


Now, icons can seamlessly adapt to your brand identity and design language.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Key Features of Popcons


‚úî One-Click Editing ‚Äì Instantly modify icons and compare different styles, just like fonts

‚úî 6 Thickness Levels ‚Äì Easily adjust the weight to fit your design

‚úî 4 Styles ‚Äì

* Line ‚Äì Clean and minimal outline style

* Solid ‚Äì Bold and filled for strong emphasis

* Line Color ‚Äì Customizable stroke color for additional versatility

* Full Color ‚Äì Vibrant and expressive icon style

‚úî 3 Roundness Options ‚Äì Adjust corner roundness to match your aesthetic

‚úî Decorative Additions ‚Äì Enhance icons with additional design elements

‚úî Seamless Figma Integration ‚Äì A smooth, intuitive workflow for designers



-------------------------------------------------------------------------


How Can You Use Popcons?


* UI/UX Design ‚Äì Maintain a consistent icon style across web and mobile apps

* Brand Identity ‚Äì Adjust icons to align with your brand‚Äôs design system

* Presentations & Infographics ‚Äì Visually compelling icons for effective communication

* Developer Collaboration ‚Äì Keep icons flexible and adaptable within a design system

* Quick Style Testing & Comparison ‚Äì Instantly switch between styles and compare different options



-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Why Choose Popcons?


* Font-Like Customization ‚Äì Modify icons dynamically without replacing them

* Time-Saving Workflow ‚Äì Instantly compare and apply different styles with a single click

* Design Consistency ‚Äì Ensure uniformity across your project with structured customization

* Highly Flexible ‚Äì Adapt icons to fit various use cases effortlessly



-------------------------------------------------------------------------


Popcons ‚Äì Make Your Icons Pop, Instantly.

plugins.name: Handoff
plugins.description:
Design ü§ù Dev Handoff


Design to dev done right. A Figma plugin to turn design variabes + styles into Tailwind & POSTCSS.


Learn more on Github.


Features


- Convert Figma variables + styles to Tailwind config variables

- Convert Figma text styles to POSTCSS syntax with responsive media queries

- Consolidate design + dev tokens into one source of truth, extensible by designers and developers


Usage


1. Install the plugin from the Figma Community

2. Open the plugin from the Figma toolbar

3. Generate handoff files (.json and .postcss) from the plugin

4. Pass files to developers to integrate into their Tailwind config and Tailwind `@component` layers


Text Styles


The plugin will convert Figma text styles to POSTCSS syntax with responsive media queries. The plugin will also generate a JSON file with the font sizes. The plugin is opinionated as to what gets converted to a class, so it's recommended to review the generated POSTCSS file and adjust as needed.


The POSTCSS file will work from the smallest breakpoint to the largest, assigning media queries using Tailwind's `screen` function as breakpoints appear. Properties are diffed to the base style and only novel properties are added to the media query.

.body-1 {
font-family: Inter;
font-size: 16px;
line-height: 24px;
font-weight: 400;
letter-spacing: 0.5px;

@media screen(md) {
font-size: 2.75rem;
}

@media screen(lg) {
font-size: 3.5rem;
}
}


Naming Schema


The naming schema works so that we capture only the most important classes. For the sake of brevity, we only capture the default classes, defined as not having any variants or as being named the `default` variant.


{viewport}/{style}/{variant}


- `viewport` - The viewport size in Tailwind syntax (e.g. `sm`, `md`, `lg`, `xl`). This corresponds directly to the `Screens` variables, so a matching entry should exist in that variable collection.

- `style` - The Figma text style name, such as `display-1` or `body-3`. This is semantic and can be named anything, but it should be consistent across the design system. The styles for this should be the _default_ styles, as in the most common styles used in the design system for this type of text.

- `variant` - The variant of the style in semantic or property synax, such as `bold`, `italic`, `uppercase`, `lowercase`, `capitalize`, `normal`, `underline`, `line-through`, `no-underline`. This is optional and can be omitted if the style does not have a variant. NOTE: A `default` style MUST be named here in order to be converted to POSTCSS (ex: `md/body-3/default`).


Variables


The plugin will convert Figma variables and effects styles to Tailwind config variables via a resulting JSON file matching the Tailwind configuration. The plugin is optimized to account for a few key properties such as `screens`, `spacing`, `backdropBlur`, `blur`, `borderRadius`, etc, which are numbers converted specially to corresponding formats. The ability to customize a properties format is in the works. Need it sooner? Open an issue and we can prioritize it.


NOTE Library names *must* match the proper Tailwind config name in order to extend the configuration properly.


{
"colors": {
"primary": "#FF0000",
"secondary": "#00FF00",
"tertiary": "#0000FF"
},
"spacing": {
"1": "0.25rem",
"2": "0.5rem",
"3": "0.75rem"
},
"screens": {
"sm": "640px",
"md": "768px",
"lg": "1024px",
"xl": "1280px"
}
}

accepted.name: The DataFace
accepted.description: A digital agency, specializing in data visualization

plugins.tagline: Design to dev with Tailwind in mind

plugins.name: Text Style Creator
plugins.description:
What This Plugin Does

  1. Creates local text styles from any selected text layer
  2. Preserves all typography variable connections (font family, size, weight, etc.)
  3. Automatically finds and applies styles to all matching text layers in the current page


How to Use

  1. Select any text layer that you want to create a style from
  2. Run the plugin


The text style will be named using the content of the selected text layer

The plugin will automatically apply the new style to all text layers with matching properties


Key Features

Supports all typography variables

Batch processing: select multiple text layers to create multiple styles at once

Intelligent matching: finds all text layers with identical properties


Preserves variable connections for:

  1. Font family
  2. Font size
  3. Font style
  4. Font weight
  5. Line height
  6. Letter spacing
  7. Paragraph spacing
  8. Paragraph indent


Note: Make sure your text layers have the desired properties before creating styles, as these will be preserved in the created style.
plugins.tagline: Create local text styles, preserving variable bindings and auto-applying to matching layers.

plugins.name: Logo Light
plugins.description:
Transform Color Logos to Clean White Versions


Logo Light is a powerful Figma plugin that quickly converts any color logo or image into a clean, professional white version with transparent background‚Äîperfect for dark backgrounds, presentations, and mockups.


Key Features

‚ú® Instant Transformation - Convert any color logo to white with a single click

üñºÔ∏è Supports All Image Formats - Works with JPEG, PNG, SVG, and any other image format in Figma

üì§ PNG Output - Creates clean PNG files with transparency for maximum flexibility

üéõÔ∏è Advanced Controls - Fine-tune the result with contrast and threshold adjustments

üîç Preview - See your white logo in real-time against a dark background

üéØ Multiple Modes - Choose from three conversion methods for perfect results:


Luminance - Best for detailed logos with gradients

Silhouette - Ideal for solid logos and simple shapes

Threshold - Perfect for high-contrast conversion with clean edges


Why You Need This Plugin

Designers frequently need white logo versions for dark mode interfaces, mockups, and presentations. Instead of manually tracing or recreating logos, Logo Light automates this process with precise results in seconds. It works with any image format, including JPEG files that typically don't support transparency, and outputs clean PNGs with transparent backgrounds.

How to Use


Select any image or logo in your Figma document (JPEG, PNG, SVG, etc.)

Click "Generate Logo" in the plugin

Adjust settings to perfect the result

Click "Create in Figma" to add the white version to your document


The generated white logo maintains the exact proportions of your original and is placed right next to it for easy access.

Perfect For


Creating dark mode versions of websites and apps

Converting JPEGs and other non-transparent formats to clean white PNGs

Designing presentation templates with consistent branding

Building mockups with white logo variations

Preparing press kits with logo alternatives

Maintaining brand asset libraries with all logo variants


Feedback and Support

We're constantly improving Logo Light based on user feedback. If you have suggestions, encounter any issues, or need assistance, please reach out to us via our support email or website.

Transform your logos in seconds with Logo Light ‚Äî the essential tool for every designer's toolkit!
plugins.tagline: Transform color logos to white with a single click

plugins.name: Paint Mixer - Try for FREE
plugins.description:
Paint Mixer allows you to blend two colors just like in real life, using Kubelka & Munk algorithm to predict how light interacts with mixed pigments under natural light for the most authentic results. Learn More from this video.


Features

  1. Accurately mix two colors using the Kubelka & Munk theory.
  2. Apply the mixed color as a fill or stroke to Figma layers.
  3. Create a 9-step gradient layer and linear-fill layer from the start and end colors.


How to Use

  1. Select the end color from the palette box below.
  2. Rotate the handle clockwise to gradually mix the start color with the end color. Rotate counterclockwise to unmix.
  3. Click the hex code to copy color.
  4. Hover on the dropdown to show more actions (see image 2).
  5. Double-click one of the palettes to change its color.


Tips

  1. Rotate two full revolutions (720¬∞) to completely turn into the end color.
  2. Click 3 dots at the bottom to show more options.
  3. Grabbing the handle further from the center of the wheel gives you more precise control.


Pricing

  1. 10 free actions with full access to all features. Actions include using the mixed color and opening the plugin.
  2. Unlock unlimited access for a one-time purchase.


Credits

  1. This plugin uses spectral.js to handle color mixing which is licensed under the MIT License.
  2. Inspiration from Paper app for iPad.
plugins.tagline: Realistic color blending using Kubelka-Munk theory

plugins.name: sticky-color-counter
plugins.description:
Count the number of stickies by color.

Able to calculate the product by giving each color sticky a unique coefficient.

The sum of the product can be viewed.


The following colors of stickies have their own coefficients by default.

  1. blue: 0.5
  2. green: 1
  3. yellow: 2
  4. red: 3
  5. else: 0
plugins.tagline: Count the number of stickies by color.

plugins.name: Generators & Sync Styles
plugins.description:
Create and Synchronize Local Color and Text Styles


Effortlessly create local color styles from selected frames and rectangles, while also generating global text styles from selected text layers. This plugin streamlines your design process by ensuring consistency across your project.


How it Works:


Selection: Simply select any frames, rectangles, or text layers within your Figma document.

Style Generation: Run the plugin to automatically generate local color styles based on the fill colors of the selected objects. For text layers, global text styles will be created based on the selected text properties.


Synchronization: The plugin intelligently synchronizes identical elements by matching both colors and text styles. Any duplicate styles will be updated accordingly, maintaining a cohesive look throughout your design.


With a clean interface and efficient workflow, this plugin enhances your design efficiency and style management.


Important!

The name of each color style will match the corresponding layer name, while the name of each text style will correspond to the selected text layer name. You can use a "/" in either layer name to organize your styles into groups. All styles will be arranged from largest to smallest based on their size.
plugins.tagline: Effortless style creation and synchronization for your designs!

plugins.name: Slice by guides
plugins.description:
You can use this plugin to create slices along horizontal Guidelines. This is a convenient tool for further export of the sliced ‚Äã‚Äãlayout.


Instructions:

1) Select the Frame that you want to divide into slices.

2) Add Guidelines, along which the division into slices will be carried out in the future.

3) Run the plugin.


The result of the plugin's work is the "Slice" elements added in the selected Frame, which can be used for export. To do this, simply select these slices and export them in a format convenient for you.
plugins.tagline: Creates slices inside a Frame along horizontal Guidelines

plugins.name: Spymaster
plugins.description: Use this plugin to generate a 5x5 grid of words that are secretly assigned to either the red or blue team. Spymasters have a separate page where they can view a map of the assigned colors and give clues to their team to guess which words belong to which team.
